headline: German Spaetzle Dumplings
description: A side of spaetzle is pure comfort. These noodle-like German dumplings are easy to mix up, then boiled in water and given a quick sauté in butter. Yum!

video.description: These traditional German dumplings are boiled then fried in butter.
video.name: German Spaetzle Dumplings

name: German Spaetzle Dumplings

recipeInstructions.text: Fill a large pot halfway full with water and bring to a boil. Adjust heat so water just simmers.
Meanwhile, mix together flour, nutmeg, salt, and white pepper in a medium bowl.
Whisk eggs together in a small bowl. Add eggs alternately with milk to dry ingredients. Stir until smooth.

Working in batches, press dough through a spaetzle maker, or through a large-holed colander or metal grater, into simmering water. Cook 5 to 8 minutes. Remove with a slotted spoon or spider and drain well.
Melt butter in a large skillet. Add spaetzle and cook, stirring gently, until heated through. Serve sprinkled with parsley.

review.reviewBody: Excellent recipe. Authentic, traditional taste! Lecker!

Sehr gut! I like this recipe. It is portion-friendly and easy to double if needed. The nutmeg makes it taste like Christmas and the white pepper gives it a little punch. This is my go-to side when I make pork loin.

I left out the nutmeg and sautéed it in lemon pepper with butter. Also, I substituted a one-to-one gluten free flour. I had to add just a touch more water to get the right consistency. It turned out delicious and the perfect consistency. I was afraid the noodles would fall apart with the flour substitute, but it worked well.

It is not "Spaetzel", it is pronounced "Spaetzl-A", soft "a". In German, the "e" at the end of a word has an English "A" sound. I used a grater and pushed the dough through with a spoon. It turned out well. I will cut the nutmeg amount in half next time, though.

Very very yum!! I made this to accompany Chicken Paprikash, and was very satisfied. I used whole wheat flour (hubby is diabetic) and they came out very well, not as light as with white flour, be extremely good. Instead of bacon grease, I fried mine in butter until they were just slightly brown. I didn't have a spaetzle maker, and tried something that worked but not well. Next time, and there will be a next time, I will try something else.

Nice recipe. I've made this a dozen times and have adjusted the seasoning depending on what I am serving it with. Extra cracked black pepper and powdered onion & garlic when its for stroganoff, Italian seasoning for my son with parmesan, Romano & mozzarella, and even use these as dumplings in my homemade chicken soup. I use a hopper style spaetzle maker and it is worth every penny. Kids love these and a great batter for them to help make.
Perfect. I lived in Germany many years and loved spaetlze. None of the pre-made bagged brands come close to home-made. Loved this recipe, simple and easy to whip up fast.
So good and so easy! No changes. Made just enough for 2 people. Served with a pot roast and gravy.
My go-to recipe for spaetzle. I always make this recipe as written - I particularly love the nutmeg in this.
My godmother Margot made these for me as a child. I like a bit more nutmeg yet these taste really good. I paired my sparrows with sausage and sweet peppers
Delicious! Made with a pork schnitzel.
VERY good! Must try!! It's messy if you don't have a spatzel press!
Just like the spätzle we had in Germany.

I just made these. My first time making spaetzle. I was scared, but it was a success!! The only thing I did different was double the recipe and use half the amount of nutmeg because it’s such a potent spice. It was perfect and I don’t recommend leaving it out. I let the “dough” rest for 30 minutes before using my flat cheese grater as the tool. I also watched a couple YouTube videos just to see what the consistency should be since I’ve never made it before and this recipe was spot on. I made to go with chicken paprikash. It was so easy and they are so delicious I will find other uses for this recipe soon!!!
They tasty and easy to make!
Excellent taste...easy to make. This recipe is my new “go to” for German accompaniment.

Followed recipe exactly. I had to add some milk because the dough was too thick for spaetzle maker (shallow metal can I drilled holes in). However, the texture was exactly like the spaetzle I had at Christmas markets in Germany. This is a keeper. I added cheese to mine because I like cheese.

I agree with the other poster, batter is too thin with the listed ratio. I used 1.5 cups flour, and could have added more (I use a Goldspatz short press). Also, I was out of milk, so I used half and half,and was pleased with the way it came out. I like the idea of a little onion powder, but feel that the nutmeg is a must. Reminds of what my mom made when I was a kid
I added another 1/2 c of flour based on other reviews. The dough was difficult to work with but the spaetzle was amazing. Loved it!

I made this recipe, and it was fantastic. It was my first attempt, and I only had a traditional box grater to work with. The grater worked perfectly, and the process was much simpler than I imagined. I sautéed the dumplings with bacon fat and thyme. Super delicious. Next time I will add crumbled bacon! Served it with blaukraut and bratwurst...simply perfection...thank you!!

This is by far the best and easiest spaetzle recipe I've found. I followed the recipe exactly, but cut the nutmeg by half. It can really overpower the dumplings.

Make sure the dough feels like dough and isn't too runny. Mix throughly until smooth and it has a bit of "stretch." 

I have a potato masher with perfect sized holes. I spread the dough in small amounts over the holes and push through to the water. Works like a charm.

Delicious, tender and a crowd-pleaser.
Didn't like the nutmeg.

This was a delicious spaetzle recipe! I used my spaetzle maker and they came out so yummy and buttery. I will say that my spaetzle were a bit too small and spherical at first so I had to add more milk (3 teaspoons?) to make the dough come out more in the shape of spaetzle.

I made the recipe as instructed except I switched water for milk since I didn’t have any on hand and probably used a bit more than a cup of flour. I didn’t sauté with butter or anything and used it as a side for Jägerschnitzel. It was amazing!

All I did was increase the eggs to offset any milk. The review from rating by "German Spaetzle Dumplings - ProudMarineWife" - is SPOT ON! Thanks for reviews from Austrian & German cooks! And thanks to AllRecipes for including all these excellent variations!
This recipe is absolutely PERFECT! I have a spaetzle maker and this was my first time making spaetzle. I was almost too easy because there is no excuse not to make it often
So easy! Family loves it!,

Made it exactly as in the recipe. I bought a Spaetzle maker on Amazon specifically to make these. The shape turned out well. It had an odd chewyness to it which I don't remember the ones from germany being so heavy. Also The nutmeg was too much. I guess I usually associate nutmeg with sweeter instead of savory recpipes so it was a little off-putting.
Great receipe! I added a little more nutmeg and white pepper for a little more flavor.
The hardest part of this recipe is finding something to strain the batter through to make the noodles. I finally used a slotted spatula that was wide enough and had holes big enough.

I agree with some of the other posters about doubling the amount of flour. The amount of milk also should be done by eye. If you plan to make this recipe often, I suggest investing in a real German spaetzle maker. It makes the process so much easier than trying to improvise. I'm very fond of German food, being part German ancestry, so I love making their food.
Followed it exactly and watched the video. It was great and was a thumbs up from the family. We added a little Parmesan cheese on top at the end.
So easy and very tasty! I have made these before, but this was the first time I sauteed them.!!!!Yummy!
Great recipe. Runny dough is great to feed through a spetzale maker.

I've made it as written which is great! This time I substituted some sour cream for some of the milk and some brown rice flour for some of the white flour ( just to get rid of it) the sour cream added a little zip to them! Try it! I had zero problems with it ever being to runny?? I use cutting board method rather than grater etc - so much easier and less mess!! Videos are online
Excellent! I kept to the recipe and it came out great!
Easy to make and absolutely delicious. My 84 year old German mom loved these!
Good, but better without the nutmeg.

Made this tonight. The batter was pretty thick. I tried to get the batter through my colander and it didn't work. So I got my flat grater out. I put the batter on that it is went through the grater in a big blob. So, I sort of cut it up in the boiling water so it wouldn't come out horrible.
The directions said saute in butter. But it didn't say for how long. I tried it after sautéing it and it had no flavor. I was going to serve it without a sauce. So, I added some extra salt to give it some flavor. If I make this again I will make it as my mom did by putting the batter on a cutting board . Then making a thin line of batter on the board and using a knife cut and push the batter into the water. 
My husband said to just be readymade stuff and not deal with it. Maybe he is right.
I added another handful of flour at the end, as I felt the dough was too loose. Very forgiving, and I used fresh nutmeg - it made these amazing!

I was skeptical about this turning out since I had never made it before, amd the dough seemed a bit loose but it was great! I did double the recipe, as another reviewer suggested, amd added a bit of Garlic powder in addition to nutmeg. I used this to make Kase Spaetzle from this site. super delicious and I will definitely be making this again!!

I have gone through a lot of batter trying to make this. Finally, I just stopped cooking them in water for the allotted time. only for about 1 min. And I made smaller batches. if you over fill the frying pan...it starts to steam and then turn to mush. boiling them for longer then 1 min, also resulted in mush. I have the spaetzle tool...so not sure what I'm doing wrong. but the finally product was awesome
These were the best Spaetzle's I have made after trying several recipes. They turned out perfectly, very authentic in my opinion. My only advice is to double the recipe!
I made this recipe to use as noodles in my homemade chicken soup. We loved. it.
Made a few times now exactly as written. The nutmeg really makes this good. Should have doubled up tonight, theres hardly any leftovers.

I had no pasta left and thought I'd give this a try with ingredients I had available: whole wheat flour, water, eggs, and salt. (no nutmeg or milk.) I let them boil for a few minutes then transferred to iron skillet with melted butter. Sauteed until some pieces started turning a little golden. It was OK. Next time, I will salt the water and add another egg to the batter to see how that works up. It is a really quick way to make homemade "pasta".
Pretty good, I like the Kaese Spaetzle Recipe more though

I couldn't find my Mother in law's original Polish Spaetzle recipe so I tried this, made it as written with a real spaetzle maker. It was very similar in taste and texture. I did not like the nutmeg. I made the 6 person serving which fed three with no leftovers. As others stated, next time I make the effort to make it I'll quadruple the recipe and freeze leftovers.

I enjoy carmelized onions mixed in and baked @ 250° for 30 min or so when I have time.

An easy way to do instead of a grater or strainer is to use a disposable pastry bag or zip loc bag with a small tip cut off and squeeze them into the water. I have a spaetzle maker but this is just so easy and no mess to clean up.

Absolutely delicious, but the dough is a little more firm than I expected, so I had a tough time pushing it through my colander with a spoon LOL. I think I'll try to find one of the spaetzle making tools as seen in the video for next time, it will be well worth.

Made this per the directions. Good basic recipe for spaetzle. Incidently, spaetzle in German means little birds or sparrows. I increased the recipe two-fold based on other reviewers comments. It was barely enough for three people. If the original recipes serves six, five of them must be sparrows!
it works just as well with normal pepper

Very easy to work with this dough. It flowed wonderfully through my Spaetzle press. I was afraid of the nutmeg because I thought the taste would be too strong. I only added about 1/8 of a tsp and next time I will be braver! I also added more like 1/2 tsp pepper and a Tbls of dried chives. Served with chicken schnitzel and made a gravy of onion mushroom and homemade chicken stock. Excellent! Thanks!
Just like it said

One of the best and easiest recipes I have used. I have made this for hundreds of people and always get rave reviews. Have even been told it was as good as their grandmother's, who still lives in the old country.

I made this with the exact ingredients listed and used a colander to press the dough through. It came out perfectly and delicious!! Thank you, I'll definitely be making this again and might even treat myself to a spaetzle maker in the future!! :D
Amazing, family loved it!

I do not have spaetzle maker. I put the batter into a metal or glass bowl. I start to pour the batter into the water and use a knife to cut the dough as it drops. It works. I have read other recipes on the web and they do the same. I looked at makers on different websites and decided I did not need another appliance in my kitchen. This recipe is really good.
Super easy to make and tasted amazing!!! Made it 2 days in a row because my son wanted more the next day!

I made it very simple. Flour salt milk eggs water. We had it with pork steak. I doubled the recipe and had no left overs. Reminded me of my mom's Spazln back in Tirol. Next time I will saute them with some onions. Maybe my picky children will still like them.
Double it right away!
It was good, a bit more gummy than the one I've used before, but we liked it with brown gravy and pork chops.
Made exactly as directed and served with jaegerschnitzel and red cabbage. I really enjoyed the subtle flavor. Thanks for sharing!

Good and easy recipe. I made the batter a wee bit too thin so they came out a little more stringy than I like. But there will be a next time so lesson learned. That’s the fun of cooking. It’s always an experiment!
I sub non-dairy milk and add a splash more nutmeg, always delicious.

substitute 1/3 cup rye flour to 2/3 cup ap, 1/2 tsp ground carraway [kummel] for the nutmeg, increase salt to full 1 tsp.

just for an interesting change.
So sticky that I couldn't push it through. All of it ended up in the trash as a sticky mess and I ate PB and J instead. Complete disappointment.

Recipe is excellent. I didn't have a spaetzle maker so I used a frosting bag with a small tip and squeezed pieces directly into the pot of boiling water. Just like gnocchi, they will sink but then float to the top when done. I gave this 4 stars instead of 5 because I found the nutmeg just a tiny touch too strong so would reduce it just a little. It. Also the parsley at the end clashed with the flavour of the nutmeg so I ended up scraping it off and won't use next time. Delicious and super easy!
loved it! Household favorite

I loved this! It was surprisingly easy, and I was sooooo pleased with how great this turned out. I poured it over a cheese grater with a cookie cookie, to move it back and forth (kind of like in the video). Thanks for this recipe!!
Turned out great. I made it just as the recipe said. I browned the spaetzle a bit more than called for. Will definitely make this again.
This is the first time I made spaetzle. The flavor and texture was great. Four stars instead of 5 due to the mess I made. I fried it with garlic, bacon bits and mushrooms. Will be making again!
I ran the mix through a potato ricer directlyinto boiling water. Next time I'll try getting longer noodles by forcing it through the ricer faster.
Delicious!
Made them with the german rouladen recipe. It was wonderful. No changes. 5 stars on both recipes
I followed exactly, and it was awesome! Added sauteed onions and butter.

I followed the recipe exactly and they turned out great. They were just the right consistency. I have a spätzle maker and t worked perfectly. It is definitely something I would make again for beef burgundy or stroganoff instead of noodles or rice.

This recipe was perfect. I definitely recommend getting a spaetzle maker, as I used a colander and it was really messy. I make spaetzle about once a year and that’s only because it’s a messy project. I am buying a spaetzle maker now so that I can make it more. This recipe is perfect, very flavorful and a hit with the entire family.
All the ingredients I already had. So easy and delicious. Made pork and sauerkraut in the crockpot. Match made in heaven. Will use this recipe to add into goulash soup.
Less nutmeg for a double batch, more flour for double batch. Delish

This is my second time attempting to leave a review - the site decided to delete my first one when I hit the "made it" button, and wouldn't allow me to leave the dialog box without adding a rating, which was blank and overwrote my first submission - not a very smartly designed website.

I referenced Cooking MaMa's review prior to making and found, as she did, that the recipe as stated leaves you with a dough that isn't quite right - it was too sticky to properly work; thus, the rating. However I was able to remedy the problem on the fly by dusting the dough with a little extra flour a few times. I believe I ended up using about an extra quarter cup, give or take.

I decided to go more traditional and press the dough out to about 1/4" with my hand and then cut ~1//4" strips with a dough knife, which I then cut by eye resulting in pre-cooked pieces of about a cube shape to about a one inch strip. This method results in less uniform noodles with little pits and grooves that hold sauce well - one of the things I really like about this type of noodle. 

I tossed about 15-20 pieces at a time into well-salted rolling water and spidered them out once they floated to the top (about a minute or so), and into a colander to drain and cool. The resulting noodle was just al dente', which should be about perfect when I cook them later this evening in herbed (sage, thyme, tarragon) brown butter with porcini.

Excellent spaetzle. I suggest getting a spaetzle maker, life is much easier. Can be had for under 20$. Well worth it if you plan to do this more than once or prepare for a group. Once you love spaetzle try the “Kasaspaetzle” , it could become a family favorite.

It was much more simple to make than I thought it would be, and I'm only fourteen years old. However, this may be due to the fact that I omitted the pepper and nutmeg as my parents are not huge fans of them. They cooked in about 2-3 minutes, rather than five, with the heat all of the way up and the lid off. In my opinion, they are great raw, but we are planning to eat them with a cheesy sauce. I didn't have a good way to mold them, so I poured the batter onto a cutting board and sliced strips into the water with a butter knife. 10/10 recommend, especially if you're looking for an easy, unique meal.
Never having eaten this before, I invited friends over that has had it. They said the taste was spot on. I LOVED it!

This recipe was so good and easy. I bought the stainless steel spaetzle maker on amazon for 13.00. It comes with a plastic scraper. I had to add a little more flour as it was too runny. Omitted the nutmeg. Great in chicken soup or with just butter. First time making.
Easy and tasty!
I really liked the spaetzle, but I had to double the milk to make it thin enough to go through the spaetzle maker.

I used this recipe to make spaetzle and it turned out great! I had to add alittle more milk to get it to the same consistency as the video. I should of doubled the recipe my kids were begging for more. Will definitely be adding this to my dinner rotation.
Love this recipe as it is!
The spaetzle were very good but the nutmeg was a little overwhelming. The next time I make this I plan to adjust the amount of nutmeg used.
Great recipe. I recommend using the cutting board and knife/pastry cutter method instead of a grater for getting the shapes.
Daughter just came back from a trip to Germany, thought these spaetzle noodles were just like the ones she had there.
Very traditional and delicious. Try making it several hours ahead of time and keep it refrigerated until ready to use. It develops a nice flavor and mellows the nutmeg. So very yummy.

I used King Arthur Measure for Measurem but otherwise the ingredients were used as noted. However "pushing it through a sieve " was for the birds. I got out a frosting bag and made them like funnel cakes. No muss no fuss and they turned out beautifully. I figured they are both German, so one method or the other made no difference.

I have made this recipe several times. It is easy just a bit time consuming but that is OK. The flavor is excellent and it tastes really good with the Sirloin Tips and Mushrooms recipe from this website. If you want to vary from the usual side of potatoes, this makes a perfect substitute for them. Serve it with stewed meat or pork. It will change your perspective and definitely will get you away from the usual potato based side. I have a spatzle maker and the recipe sometimes comes out a bit runny. Do not fret, just add flour in tablespoons and test until you notice it becomes firm enough to your taste. My suggestion is to add a few more tablespoons of flour and that will be it. If you want to store them, I recommend doing so after you have fried them to keep them from sticking to each other.
Easy and delicious
Too much nutmeg, Kids! Other than that, sehr gut!
Very easy to make and tastes just like we had in Germany. we've made twice now - will definitely be making again.
Made as per recipe.worked great will use in future
